Looks good.  @isper3at , yes catching the exception prevents the drops because it will keep going rather than crapping out on individual adds -- that was why there was a catch for that exception in the original dao before we introduced the batch writing stuff.
I'm going to hold off on merging this for a minute.  This exception talk has me thinking there are other exceptions that we are not processing correctly. brb

The more I look at this, the more I’m confident that this has to more with the mongo libs and not anything that we wrote for Rya. I’ll try to put together an example tomorrow.
Oh, and this builds for me.  yay.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/incubator-rya-master-with-optionals-pull-requests/517/
RYA-397 was the rename of mockmongo stuff,  RYA-398 was fixing the `MongoEntityIndexTest`
Caleb, RYA-353 handles the Test to IT refactor.
merged in a2ebefe

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/incubator-rya-master-with-optionals-pull-requests/518/

@ejwhite922 There's a couple issues with the batch writer and it doesn't have to do with exceptions being caught.  (1) the QueueFullChecker thread should not be a daemon thread.... "The Java Virtual Machine exits when the only threads running are all daemon threads" means that the JVM will exit while flushing to mongo.  (2) It doesn't seem like the secondary indexer (i.e. geoindexer) is flushed when I close down the sail layer.  Can you double check that?

Also, it seems like the JVM takes a very long time to exit after I call sailrepository.shutDown().  I think has to do with the BatchWriter as well.

Oh, and this built for me fine.
wrt to the secondary flushes -- I think there is a jira ticket already for secondary indexers not being flushed appropriately.  You should see whether Aaron's comment is a relic of that or not.

asfbot build

I tried creating a build on b.a.o with the coverage profile enabled and "record jacoco report" plug-in enabled.

You can check on it's progress here: https://builds.apache.org/job/incubator-rya-master-with-optionals-with-coverage/

I'll roll these changes into the master builds once this PR is pulled in.

There is another JIRA ticket for indexers not being flushed: [RYA-72](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/RYA-72).  I went ahead and addressed that in this ticket and had the DAOs flush all indexers whenever they flush.

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/incubator-rya-master-with-optionals-pull-requests/531/
you have 2 commits that have the same message with different hashes, can you clean that up and get this to build?

@isper3at Sorry I cannot undo that. This is taking a lot more effort that I initially thought because of the geoindexing.  I'm thinking about closing this PR and open a new one when I have this compiling. 
I think we should create a new branch for this. What do you think ?

I'm checking out your commit now to see why geoindexing would give you grief.
I don't think a new PR is required, we can just not do the review until after it builds, change the title to start with [WIP]
So I found why. I tested the minicluster in a new project alone and it works fine. Seems to be the Pom.xml I will push my other commits that are local until now
I'm still confused as to why your commits are overlapping so much and why you can't squash the commits.
Because The changes are not trivial...
Can we create tasks for each point that need change ?
the  complexity of the changes shouldn't matter to git, I was able to squash all the commits into 1 with no conflicts.  I am still seeing compile errors in GeoFunctionsIT

sure, something of this scale, it would be nice to have it split up into smaller commits.  Do you not have create issue rights on Jira?  If not, let me know which tickets need making and I'll link you to them all, 

*edit*
just saw @ejwhite922  comments, yours was probably to those

I am able to reproduce the three tests failures above.  It hopefully has to do with the tests.  They are kind of a fridge area since all the other queries work fine.  With this change, we can no longer expect a string object in the query to match a URI object in the data, and the reverse.  

Strings are formed by new RyaType(String) and URI objects are formed by new RyaURI(String).

I am off to work on other things.  Hopefully I'll come back to this.  Feel free to tackle it yourself!
